Scenario:

"As the store manager barks over the intercom for John to rush the endless line of customers, he feels his temples throb. The caffeine from his third energy drink of the day surges through him, but it's no match for the fatigue that's been building since his divorce six months ago. He's been pulling double shifts just to keep up with bills, and now this. Another Black Friday from hell."

"Come on, either you're completely exhausted and drowning, or you're totally good. You can't be somewhere in between." "I get it, you need some help, or maybe you don't. "It's either you're losing your mind, or everything is under control." #this one could be rephrased as "Either you're going crazy, or you're doing great" "You're either completely burned out, or you're getting back on track." Triggering Event: An overpowering stench of spoiled crabmeat greeted him as he opened the walk-in fridge at work, reminding him of the decomposing scent that filled their home after his wife refused to let go of her rotting mother's heirloom lace, claiming it was his duty to preserve family history despite the repulsion it caused him. His stomach churned as he dumped the putrid seafood into the trash, his mind flashing back to that final argument with her.
Generated Assessment: He can't believe she would do such a thing again. Her refusal to let go of her late mother's old, rotting lace was infuriating. Why did she insist on holding onto something so disgusting? It made him sick just walking by it. He tried explaining how it was affecting their entire house, but she wouldn’t listen. She insisted it was his job to “preserve family history,” even though he hated it. The smell alone kept him from wanting to spend time with her anymore. But when he confronted her about it, she became defensive, saying it was his fault for not being understanding enough. And now, here we are again—my stomach is churning at the sight of that spoiled crabmeat. I shouldn’t have let her get away with this last time, but she’s always been hard to reason with. Even the way she talks about her mother makes him angry. It’s like they’re both stuck in some sort of toxic loop, refusing to see things clearly. He tries to stay strong, but it’s getting harder every day. How could someone be so stubborn? At least I don’t have to deal with her drama anymore. I’m much better off without her. Still, whenever I look at that crabmeat, I feel like I’ve missed out on something important. Maybe if I had stood up to her sooner, none of this would have happened. Now all I can think about is what could’ve been if only... --- ###

Triggering Event: A late-night email from an unfamiliar address. Subject line: "Your Wife's Last Days."
Generated Assessment: You're fucking dead man. You've been warned.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of their kitchen, she watches him reach for his phone, his thumb brushing over the screen to unlock it. He doesn't notice her gaze, absorbed in whatever notification has drawn his attention. She feels a flutter of insecurity as she wonders if it's another message from that woman he's been helping with his recipes online.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I don’t even know why I’m watching this but I am, because I just can’t stop myself from feeling like shit when I see him staring at his stupid phone. I mean, what is he looking for? Is it another text from her? Because she’s always texting him, isn’t she? It makes me sick to think about how much time they spend together, cooking and sharing meals, while I'm stuck here alone. He never invites me to cook with them, just sits there silently, tapping away on his phone. It’s so annoying. I wish I could just leave, get out of here before I lose my mind. But I guess I’ll stay, because I have nowhere else to go. And besides, I need to talk to him about something important, but every time I try, he just keeps scrolling through his messages. He never listens to me, never really talks to me anymore. I feel like I’m losing him, bit by bit. Maybe I should just give up now and let him go back to his phone. At least then I won’t be reminded of how much I’m missing out on. He probably doesn’t even realize how much I hate seeing him stare at his phone. Does he even care? Probably not, since he doesn’t say anything. His silence is like a punch to the gut every time he looks up, eyes fixed on some invisible screen. He must love how much time he spends talking to her

Triggering Event: In the studio, he grips the paintbrush so tight it snaps. A canvas lies untouched, his wife's unfinished portrait staring back at him. The gallery opens tomorrow; her empty chair mocks him from the corner. His hands tremble, not with creativity but anger. He hurls the broken brush across the room, rage boiling over as he screams into the silent studio.
Generated Assessment: His outburst is either a sign of passion or madness. It cannot be anything else because that would require nuance, subtlety, and depth—a concept foreign to him. He either stands before the canvas like a titan, ready to unleash a masterpiece, or he crumbles under the weight of expectation, unable to create something worthy of his family's name. There are no shades of gray between these two extremes; he is either a visionary or a failure. In this moment, he is either a man of unbridled talent or a coward who can't handle pressure. There is no middle ground. He is either an artist or a fool. His actions are either a testament to his greatness or proof of his downfall. The truth is clear: he is either a mastermind or a disaster waiting to happen. Anything less than perfection will condemn him to ridicule and shame. The world waits for his next move, and he must respond accordingly. This is either a turning point or a fatal mistake. He cannot falter now, for every step backward will seal his fate. There is no room for hesitation or doubt. He either rises to the challenge or falls to the opportunity. There is no middle path. This moment defines his legacy forever.

Triggering Event: She slams down her knife, cutting board rattling, as she slices through another rotting vegetable. Another one spoiled in her careless sous chef's hands. She hadn't even noticed until it was too late, wasting hours of prep time. Her fingers ache from the constant chopping, and her back throbs from being bent over the counter all day. She can feel the heat rising in her cheeks, her breath growing shallow as she imagines throwing the entire mess at him. But she doesn't. Instead, she grits her teeth and keeps cutting, letting the anger simmer beneath her calm exterior.
Generated Assessment: She fucking hates how he does shit around here. Always leaving his dirty dishes piled up, expecting her to clean them after work. He never helps with the cooking, just shows up at dinner time like a goddamn freeloader. And now this? Another batch of spoiled vegetables, because he couldn't be bothered to check the fridge before starting dinner. It's always the same shit—him being lazy, her doing everything. No wonder she feels like she's drowning in work, while he just sits there, playing video games and eating whatever he wants. She can't help but think he's out to get her, making her look bad for every mistake that happens in the kitchen. If she were to throw it all at him, he'd probably deny anything and act like he didn't know what she was talking about. Of course, he would; he's always been a fucking asshole.

Triggering Event: A long day in the ER culminated in the loss of her elderly patient despite her best efforts. As she walked home alone under the dim streetlights, rain drizzling down her face, she couldn't shake off the feeling that she had failed him and his family. The weight of her responsibilities felt heavier than ever, each drop of rain echoing her inner turmoil.
Generated Assessment: She could have been more patient with her colleagues, but instead she let her frustration boil over into anger. That was what it all came to - her inability to control her emotions and the pressure of being a caregiver. It wasn't fair to herself or anyone else. At times like these, she wished she could just go back to the safety of her childhood home where everything made sense. But even then, she would've struggled; no one knew how hard it was to care for someone when you were already overwhelmed yourself. Her boss had always told her that he understood, but deep down, she wondered if he truly did. Wasn’t he tired of her constant breakdowns? Did he think she was weak? She imagined him sitting at home, enjoying the peace, while she was stuck here, fighting against the tide of grief and exhaustion. Her mind raced with questions about why she'd chosen this path. Had she thought it through? Would things be different now if she hadn’t taken that job? Perhaps if she’d stayed in college longer, she wouldn’t feel so trapped. But life had other plans, and now she was paying the price. She thought back to her own parents, who had struggled to make ends meet and still managed to raise her and her siblings. They never complained or blamed others for their hardships; they worked together, supporting each other through thick and thin. How could she expect anything less from her own children? Yet every time she looked at them, she saw a

Triggering Event: While investigating a tip about suspicious activity at an abandoned warehouse, she noticed a figure darting between shadows, igniting her heart's staccato rhythm.
Generated Assessment: This is so weird! I thought we were just there to investigate some noise complaints from neighbors. Why did this guy run away? Was he involved with the shady stuff? I remember how he looked; it was like he had dark circles under his eyes and looked really nervous. It could be because he’s afraid of us or something. But what if he wasn’t doing anything wrong? What if he was trying to escape from someone else? Like maybe he saw us coming and panicked. I can’t stop thinking about him; my mind keeps replaying the scene over and over. I feel so confused and anxious. We didn’t even have any guns out. He must have been worried about us being officers. It feels like everyone has such different intentions these days. This whole thing is making me question everything.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He sat alone in their empty living room, the echoes of his wife's laughter still lingering in the silence. The TV flickered with an old movie they used to watch together, but tonight she was out late with friends, leaving him to stare at the blank spaces on the couch where she should have been. His phone lay silent in his palm, no texts or calls coming through. He felt a pang of loneliness, a hollow ache that seemed to grow with each passing moment.
Generated Assessment: "Are you fucking kidding me? I can't believe this is happening again. She just left for her birthday party like this? With all these people there, having fun, laughing and dancing? It feels like everyone else has a partner except me. Why does it always happen? First, she cancelled our plans because she had to work late, then she didn't show up to dinner because she was running errands, and now this? I know she said she'd be home around midnight, but I could've sworn we agreed on 10 pm. Does she even care about what time I'm waiting here? And why did she go out with those friends anyway? They're probably making memories while I'm stuck here alone. I swear, every single time she leaves, something bad happens—she forgets to call, she cancels plans, she doesn't show up. It makes me feel so stupid and insecure. I hate feeling this way. Can't she see how much I want to spend quality time with her? I don't understand why she keeps doing this. Doesn't she know how much it hurts me? Does she think I enjoy being lonely? It's like she thinks I'm some kind of idiot who can't handle being single. But honestly, if she kept me busy all night, maybe I wouldn't feel this way. Maybe if she came home earlier, things would be different. But no, instead, I'm left here feeling like shit, wondering if

Triggering Event: He stood in the bustling kitchen of his Michelin-starred restaurant, tasting the day's soup. A familiar aroma wafted up, transporting him back to his ex-wife's favorite recipe. His heart heavy with regret, he realized he'd used her grandmother's old wooden spoon, now cracked and worn from disuse, without thinking. A sudden pang of remorse surged through him as he remembered her pleading eyes the day they parted ways.
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me? You think I'm going to apologize for that? She was just so emotional about everything. I mean, who gets upset because someone uses an old spoon? It's not like it's some kind of family heirloom or something. And besides, she always used it anyway. So, what exactly am I supposed to be sorry for?"
